This nice-penn'd card fair Henrietta sends</br>Around to all her fashionable friends:</br>"Miss Henrietta Walsingham presents</br>To Miss Belinda Blah her compliments,</br>And asks the pleasure of her company</br>On Thursday evening next, the 5th, to tea."

Bustle begins; — and all above, below,</br>Gives note of preparation for the show.</br>Gowns, ribbons, caps, the busy parlour fill;</br>The kitchen is a scene more busy still.</br>There, maid and mistress, servants black and white,</br>Armed cap-a-pee, in common cause unite.</br>The oven flames, the stirring spoon goes round,</br>Eggs rise in foam, and labouring mortars sound.</br>Butter and flour with spice and sugar join;</br>Milk, water, cream, with isinglass combine:</br>Buns, custards, hearts and rounds, are smoking here;</br>There, jellies, syllabubs, blanc-mange appear;</br>And pound-cake, plum-cake, seed-cake, rise in state,</br>Till the full tables groan beneath the weight.

Revolving time, big with the fate of kings</br>And love-sick girls, the appointed evening brings.</br>Prompt to the call, and willing to obey,</br>First come the fair, in costly plumage gay:—</br>Like truant school-boys, backward kept by fear,</br>The tardy gentlemen at last appear.</br>The assembly now presents two stately rows:</br>On this side sit the belles, on that the beaux;</br>And thus, like hostile hosts in dread array,</br>Await the coming of the freighted tray.
The tea goes round, — they sip, and sip again,</br>Till rising fumes exhilarate the brain,</br>And broken whispers from the cautious fair,</br>Like distant music, float upon the air.

The service o'er, each sex apart unites</br>In petty groups, as choice or chance invites.</br>The conversation, first, is soft and slow;</br>More loud and quick, succeeding accents flow,</br>Till every voice in one harsh clamour stuns,</br>Like the mixt din of Babel's babbling sons.</br>"Exempli gratia," (that is, for example,)</br>Here follows, of the whole a genuine sample.

The tea is fine. — This cake is very nice.—</br>I'm glad you like it; take another slice.—</br>What is there stirring? — Nothing, sir, that's new.—</br>How is the weather out? — It rains a few.—</br>So soon divorced! — Exchange has fallen, they say.—</br>This cap is pretty. — What's the price of hay?</br>—Two ships arrived — six bride-maids — wedding cake—</br>Seven bales of broadcloth —shocking — such a rake!—</br>Ten thousand dollars — Leghorn bonnet — brandy—</br>Miss Flacket's ball — New England rum — a dandy—</br>Thirty days' passage — dances well — confined—</br>Brown sugars — three weeks old — a gale of wind—</br>Pork — muslins — Kean and Conway — salt and crates—</br>The newest fashion — Troup — the Southern States—</br>In love — engaged — at auction — dances well—</br>Five failures — Saratoga — quite a belle—</br>Molasses — baby's cap — salt fish — face veils—</br>At church — ball dress — pot-ashes — fifty bales—</br>Ice-creams — grows late — my hood and shawl — polite—</br>I thank you, dear — a glass of wine — good night.

In boreal climes, as learned travellers say,</br>Where rugged Winter reigns with tyrant sway,</br>Each word that's breathed, and every vocal sound,</br>Ere they escape, in icy chains are bound,</br>And driven in tempests o'er a frozen sea,</br>Till Spring, returning, sets the prisoners free.</br>Then, wondering sailors, traversing the deep,</br>As on the deck their nightly watch they keep,</br>Hear strange discourse, and words from sense disjoined,</br>And mingled voices, to the vacant wind.</br>Such were the wild and windy sounds that rose,</br>Confused and loud, from city belles and beaux,</br>When Henrietta's high-bred company,</br>On that proud evening, graced her rooms for tea.</br>
